Ian continually whines about "valid reasons for owning guns", claiming that self-defence is not one of them on the grounds that it is rare compared to crime (despite the things I've pointed out about his sources; but until he presents them here, let's keep that issue on that thread, shall we?). So I'd like to know what he thinks is a valid reason. Anyone else is welcome to post their views.

At this time I seem to be the only vote for "other", which is for the purposes of my answer: Any lawful purpose not listed above. 
 
 -"People who live protected lives should not make rules for those who don't"
Any reason you want. As long as it's legal to possess a firearm, you needn't specify your reason.
The second amendment. That is a valid reason that needs no further explanation. Abolish it or deal with it.

 Amen.
 
 I have reasons for needing a firearm, but I have no obligation to reveal them.
 
 I don't have to justify the necessity of having a right to be free from unreasonable search and seizure; my right to free speech, press, and assembly; my right to attend (or not attend) a church of my choice; my right to remain silent and to have the protection of a citizen composed grand jury before being made to stand trial for a felony offense; to have a trial by jury, to be free from cruel and unusual punishments; or my right not to be a slave. These rights are recognized by my Constitution, and need no further justification. The RKBA is likewise a part of that great charter, and it requires no further justification.

Justice Benjamin Cardozo, The Nature of the Judicial Process, Lecture II, 1921.
